posts.cooked: We are printing a cim adapter for versplanetary gearbox. Is this strong enough to survive matches? We are printing it at 60% infill grid pattern. What infill do you reccomend? Thanks

posts.name: Co-Head Mentor 3658
posts.cooked: We have printed ALL of the cim adapter for versplanetary gearboxes on our robot this year and they have all held up, even during intense contact matches. We however have printed them with 100 percent infill since we knew this years game would be more intense on contact with other robots than previous seasons.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: One big tip: don’t try to get your strength from high infill percentages.  Instead add perimeters and top/bottom layers.  The resulting print will be much stronger because you are no longer limited by the bond strength of the infill to the nearest solid layer.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
Seeing this video changed my thinking on this:

You’re probably right that adding shells increases strength/weight more than infill, but high infill ratios are probably very significant for part strength.

To answer OP’s question, I wouldn’t worry at all about a printed CIM adapter inside the frame perimeter. It’s not see any force, it’s just acting as a spacer.

posts.name: Fedor Leonov
posts.cooked: I say just add a lot of top/bottom walls and perimeters, then do around 100% infill. Doesn’t hurt to be safe.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: That is testing compressive loading only, which is not representative of the majority of use cases on a robot.  You do need enough infill to prevent buckling of the walls and to carry any compressive loads, but usually there is little benefit beyond about 30% infill until you are approaching a near solid part at 85%+.  Basically, adding 1 perimeter is generally more beneficial than 10% more infill and usually more efficient regarding materials use and print time.  All of this depends on appropriate design practices for printed parts of course.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
kswaid:

That is testing compressive loading only

Do you know of corresponding tests for tensile/impact strengths where shells remain constant and weight/infill percentage increases?

kswaid:

Basically, adding 1 perimeter is generally more beneficial than 10% more infill and usually more efficient regarding materials use and print time.

This definitely sounds right to me. Shells are more efficient than infill in strength to weight. There’s some testing on CNC kitchen to support your point.

Here’s what I was trying to communicate. What I used to think from hearing say people say that shells are more important than infill is that infill doesn’t matter very much at all. But that’s probably not true, if you don’t care about  weight or print time. Printing at 100% infill is probably beneficial if you care about the strength of the part.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked:
I think Stephan from CNC Kitchen has done a more complete series of tests if you dig through his channel.

And yes, 100% infill does maximize strength for a given part if you don’t have any limitations.  It should be noted, however, that solid infill also maximizes warping forces that will cause problems with materials like polycarbonate and nylon.

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked: Markforged Onyx prints great at 100% infill; I’ve literally never had a part warp.

posts.name: system

suggested_topics.title: Roborio Radio Connection Issue
suggested_topics.excerpt: From your screenshot, it’s definitely not set properly. The hostname should show as roborio-<team#>-frc.local. Connecting successfully over USB is expected since it doesn’t rely on team number.

suggested_topics.title: Swerve X covers
suggested_topics.excerpt: Does anyone have models for Swerve X covers? We want one for Swerve X Flipped, not X2. My team can design our own but I’d prefer just to get them off here to save some time.
